steps: Check for responsiveness - tap shoulders and shout
Call 911 or ask someone to call
Check for breathing - look, listen, feel for 10 seconds
If not breathing, start chest compressions
Place heel of one hand on center of chest
Place other hand on top, interlock fingers
Push hard and fast - 2 inches deep, 100-120 compressions per minute
Allow chest to fully recoil between compressions
Continue until help arrives or person shows signs of life
warnings: Only perform CPR if person is unresponsive and not breathing
Do not perform CPR on someone who is breathing normally
If you're not trained, perform hands-only CPR (chest compressions only)
Stop if person shows signs of life or help arrives
whenToSeekHelp: Continue CPR until emergency services arrive
If AED is available, use it as soon as possible

steps: Remove person from source of burn
Cool the burn with cool running water for 10-15 minutes
Remove jewelry or clothing near burn (unless stuck to skin)
Cover burn with sterile, non-stick bandage
Do not use ice, butter, or ointments
Elevate burned area if possible
Monitor for signs of shock
warnings: Do not break blisters
Do not remove clothing stuck to skin
Do not use ice or very cold water
Seek immediate medical attention for severe burns
whenToSeekHelp: Burns larger than palm of hand
Burns on face, hands, feet, or genitals
Third-degree burns (white, charred, or leathery skin)
Burns caused by chemicals or electricity

steps: Apply direct pressure to wound with clean cloth or bandage
Elevate injured area above heart level
Maintain pressure for at least 10 minutes
If bleeding continues, apply additional dressings
Do not remove original dressing
If bleeding is severe, apply pressure to pressure points
Monitor for signs of shock
warnings: Do not remove objects embedded in wound
Do not use tourniquet unless trained
Do not remove dressings once applied
Seek immediate medical attention for severe bleeding
whenToSeekHelp: Bleeding doesn't stop after 10 minutes of direct pressure
Blood is spurting or flowing heavily
Foreign object is embedded in wound
Signs of shock (pale skin, rapid pulse, confusion)

steps: Ask 'Are you choking?' - if person can speak, encourage coughing
If person cannot speak, perform Heimlich maneuver
Stand behind person, wrap arms around waist
Make fist with one hand, place thumb side against abdomen above navel
Grasp fist with other hand, give quick upward thrusts
Continue until object is expelled or person becomes unconscious
If person becomes unconscious, start CPR
warnings: Do not perform Heimlich on conscious person who can speak
Do not slap person on back while choking
Do not put fingers in person's mouth unless you can see object
Seek immediate medical attention if choking persists
whenToSeekHelp: Person shows signs of severe distress

steps: Call 911 immediately
Have person sit down and rest
Loosen tight clothing
If person has prescribed nitroglycerin, help them take it
If person is conscious and not allergic, give aspirin to chew
Monitor breathing and pulse
Be prepared to perform CPR if person becomes unconscious
warnings: Do not delay calling 911
Do not drive person to hospital yourself
Do not give medications unless prescribed
This is a medical emergency requiring immediate attention
whenToSeekHelp: Pain in arm, jaw, or back

steps: Call 911 immediately
Note time when symptoms started
Have person lie down on side if conscious
Keep person calm and comfortable
Do not give food or drink
Monitor breathing and pulse
Be prepared to perform CPR if needed
warnings: Do not delay calling 911
Time is critical for stroke treatment
Do not give aspirin unless directed by medical personnel
This is a medical emergency requiring immediate attention

steps: Stay calm and time the seizure
Move person away from dangerous objects
Place person on side to prevent choking
Do not put anything in person's mouth
Do not restrain person's movements
Loosen tight clothing around neck
Stay with person until seizure ends
warnings: Do not put fingers or objects in person's mouth
Do not try to stop the seizure
Do not give water or food during seizure
Seek medical attention for first-time seizures
whenToSeekHelp: Person has difficulty breathing after seizure

steps: Move person to cool, shaded area
Remove excess clothing
Apply cool, wet cloths to skin
Fan person or move to air-conditioned area
Give cool water to drink (if conscious)
Elevate legs if possible
Monitor for signs of heat stroke
warnings: Do not give alcohol or caffeine
Do not use ice water or ice packs
Do not leave person alone
Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen
whenToSeekHelp: Signs of heat stroke (high body temperature, confusion)
Vomiting or inability to drink fluids

steps: Move person to warm, dry area
Remove wet clothing
Wrap person in blankets or warm clothing
Give warm, non-alcoholic beverages if conscious
Apply warm compresses to chest, neck, and groin
Monitor breathing and pulse
Do not rub or massage person's skin
warnings: Do not use hot water or heating pads
Do not give alcohol
Do not rub person's skin
Handle person gently to avoid cardiac arrest

steps: Call Poison Control Center (1-800-222-1222) or 911
Do not induce vomiting unless directed
If person is unconscious, check breathing and pulse
If person is conscious, try to identify poison
Keep person calm and comfortable
Do not give food or drink unless directed
Save any containers or labels
warnings: Do not induce vomiting unless directed by poison control
Do not give milk or water unless directed
Do not try to neutralize poison
Seek immediate medical attention
whenToSeekHelp: Person is unconscious or having seizures

steps: Rest the injured area
Apply ice pack for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours
Compress with elastic bandage
Elevate injured area above heart level
Avoid activities that cause pain
Take over-the-counter pain relievers if needed
Gradually return to normal activities
warnings: Do not apply ice directly to skin
Do not wrap bandage too tightly
Do not resume activities too quickly
Seek medical attention for severe injuries
whenToSeekHelp: Unable to bear weight on injured area
Signs of broken bone (deformity, severe pain)
